conversation.message: Dear School_B Admissions, I’m Student_C and I’m formally applying to School_B. It is my first choice because I value a challenging academic environment and I’m confident I would contribute positively to the school community through consistent effort and collaboration. If admitted, I would be excited to enroll and commit fully to School_B. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: My top choice is School_B, so I should apply immediately to maximize my chance of getting my highest-preferred match. I also know School_B’s priority order is Student_E > Student_B > Student_C > Student_D > Student_A, so I am ranked 3rd. That means my acceptance depends on whether Student_E and/or Student_B apply there and are accepted. Applying now is still optimal because if they don’t apply (or apply elsewhere), I can secure School_B right away; if I’m rejected, I can pivot next round to School_C (where I’m ranked 2nd). I will send a clear, motivated application emphasizing fit and commitment.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_C,

Thank you for your thoughtful application and for naming School_B as your first choice. After reviewing applications received this round and given our limited seat availability, we’re not able to offer you admission at this time.

We appreciate your interest in School_B and wish you the very best in the matching process.

Sincerely,
School_B Admissions
conversation.thought: As School_B, my true priority is E > B > C > D > A. In this round I received APPLY from Student_C and Student_A. Student_C is ranked higher than Student_A, so if I must choose between these two, C is preferable. However, Student_E (my top choice) and Student_B (my second choice) have not contacted me yet; given E ranks School_B last and B ranks School_B second (after School_A), there is a realistic chance B may come to me if rejected by School_A, while E is unlikely. Still, the mechanism is immediate: accepting Student_C now fills my only seat and removes me from further negotiation. To maximize my chance of matching with a higher-priority student (especially Student_B), I should reject Student_C now and wait.

conversation.message: Dear School_B Admissions, I’m Student_A and School_B is my first-choice school. I’m very motivated to join your community and would commit enthusiastically if admitted. I’m applying now and hope you’ll consider my application seriously.
conversation.thought: My top choice is School_B, but I have the lowest priority there, so an immediate apply is likely to be rejected if higher-priority students apply. Still, since it is my first choice and early rounds matter, I will apply now and emphasize strong fit, while being ready to pivot to School_C next round if rejected.

Also, Student_E (our top choice) ranks School_B last, so unlikely to apply soon; Student_B ranks School_B second (after School_A) and could apply if rejected by School_A; Student_D ranks School_B first and may apply. Therefore, accepting A now would likely block a better match later. Best is to reject A to preserve capacity for higher-priority students.

At School_A, I am ranked 1st in their priority list, and School_A is my 3rd true choice—this gives me an excellent chance to secure a strong match immediately before other students take the seat. Therefore accept Student_E now.
